The Cabinet bad before them a Memorandumby the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs(Paper CP.-335 (29)) on the subject of theOperation of Dominion Legislation, setting outthe present position in regard to certain subjects which had been dealt with by a Sub-Committee underthe Chairmanship of Sir Maurice Gwyer. Theprincipal recommendations of Sir Maurice Gwyer's Sub-Committee, the acceptance of which was recom-mended in the Secretary of State's Memorandum, are set forth below:-(A) LEGISLATION WITH RESPECT TOTHE CROWN:That there should be a Constitu-tional Convention to be agreed atthe next Meeting of the ImperialConference ard, after approval bythe Dominion Parliaments, to be embodied as one of the preamblesof the Act to be passed by the parliament at Westminster, whichConvention would declare, in sub-stance, that it would be "in accord with the present constitutional position of all the members of theCommonwealth in relation to one another that any alteration in thelaw touching: the succession to the throne or the Royal Style and Titlesshall hereafter require the assentas well of the Parliaments of allthe Dominions as of the Parliamentof the United Kingdom".(B) CERTAIN ASPECTS OF DEFENCE LEGIS-LATION:That in connection with.the exerciseof extra-territorial lcgi.8la.tivepowers provision should be made whereby the troops of each memberof the Commonwealth should onjoy,when in the territories of othermembers of the Commonwealth, thecustomary extra-territorial Immunitiesas regards internal discipline.(C) THE LAW OF PRISE:That uniformity of the law of Priseand co-ordination of Prize jurisdictionshould be maintained. (D) SUGGESTED EMPIRE COURT:That the question of a tribunal forthe settlement of inter-Dope rialdisputes should be further examined by the Governments before the nextImperial Conference.After hearing statements from the Attorney-General; from the Lord Chancellor as Chairman ofthe Cabinet Committee which had discussed these .questions; and from the Prime Minister, who reported that in view of the great national Import-ance of these issues he had consulted Mr Baldwinand Mr Amery (who had agreed generally in theproposals) and Mr Lloyd George (who had not agreed),the Cabinet agreed (a) To allow the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs and the Attorney-General to sign the Report and to commit themselves to recommend theCabinet to support the r^commenda-tions in Paper CP.-335 (29) and summarised above, when they arebe-ing considered at the nextImperial Conference:(b) That as soon as the Report of theConference on the Operation ofDominion Legislation is signedit should be circulated confidential -tlally to members of the Cabinet:(c) That the Report should not bepublished until it has reached allthe Dominions:(d) To thank the Attorney-General forhis effective co-operation with theSecretary of State for DominionAffairs in this matter.
